content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Find the GitHub Skill section and how many courses are under the 'First day on GitHub' heading.  Please interact with https://github.com/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The task requires finding the GitHub Skill section and specifically counting the courses under 'First day on GitHub.' There is no clear sign of this information in the visible part of the page. I should look for links or sections that may relate to learning, resources, or skills. The "Resources" button [6] in the top navigation bar likely contains relevant links, such as documentation, skills, or learning resources.
Action: Click [6]
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "Learning Pathways" link [12] under the Resources menu is likely the section that will have GitHub Skill-related information and possibly the 'First day on GitHub' heading. I should click "Learning Pathways" to proceed and look for those details.
Action: Click [12]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I have reached the "GitHub Learning Pathways" page, which looks promising for finding the GitHub Skill section. However, the lower part of the page is blocked by a cookie consent banner. I need to dismiss this banner for better visibility and access to the content. Clicking "Accept" is the fastest way to remove this banner.
Action: Click [11]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The cookie banner is gone and the top of the "GitHub Learning Pathways" section is now fully visible. To find the GitHub Skill section and the courses under 'First day on GitHub', I need to scroll down and inspect the content further.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.5
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "Pick your pathway" section is visible, featuring different learning options, but there is no sign of the "GitHub Skill" section or the 'First day on GitHub' heading. I need to scroll further down to find the relevant sections or headings that address the task requirements.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The lower part of the "Pick your pathway" section is now visible, along with links to explore different learning pathways, but "GitHub Skill" and 'First day on GitHub' are not mentioned yet. The "Featuring expert insights from:" heading appears next, suggesting expert-related content follows, but I have not yet reached the GitHub Skill section.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.65
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The current section contains expert testimonials and quotes about GitHub products. There is still no indication of the GitHub Skill section or the 'First day on GitHub' heading. I need to continue scrolling down to locate the required sections.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.7
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The visible section still contains more testimonials from various companies and their engineers. There are now also company logos at the bottom, suggesting the end of the testimonials or a transition to another section is coming up. I have not yet seen the GitHub Skill section or the 'First day on GitHub' heading. I should continue scrolling downward.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.75
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "GitHub Learning Pathways" section is now visible, and this is likely where GitHub Skill details and pathways are introduced. There are still no specific GitHub Skill section or the 'First day on GitHub' heading shown yet, so I need to scroll down further to view the full content of this section.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.96
Completion: 0.8
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The page displays a section titled "Optimize your GitHub use through expert insight," which introduces the learning pathways but still does not reveal the specific GitHub Skill section or the 'First day on GitHub' heading. I need to keep scrolling to find the required heading and the list of courses under it.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.82
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I have reached the end of the visible content for the GitHub Learning Pathways page, and there does not appear to be a section titled "GitHub Skill" or a "First day on GitHub" heading with its related courses in view. The content provided either does not contain the required section or the pathway is hidden behind the "Start your learning pathway" button [8], which might take the user to a deeper learning module selection page.

Action: Click [8]
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.85
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "Pick your pathway" section presents several pathways (AI-powered development with GitHub Copilot, CI/CD with GitHub Actions, Shift left with GitHub Advanced Security, Administration and Governance with GitHub Enterprise), but there is still no "GitHub Skill" section or "First day on GitHub" heading on this part of the page. Further scrolling down may reveal more pathways or the needed section.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.96
Completion: 0.88
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "Pick your pathway" section lists links to specialized learning pathways (Copilot, automation, security, administration), but there is no "GitHub Skill" section or "First day on GitHub" heading. The section beneath ("Featuring expert insights from:") does not appear relevant. It's likely that the required section isn't present on this pathway overview and may be accessible by exploring one of these learning pathway links, or it may be housed elsewhere on the site.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Confidence: 0.7
Completion: 0.88
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I still do not see the "GitHub Skill" section or the "First day on GitHub" heading. Since the navigation bar includes a "Learn" button [4], it is possible that the learning and skills areas—including new user onboarding like "First day on GitHub"—are housed under that menu.
Action: Click [4]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.88
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "Learn" dropdown is open, revealing links to "GitHub Learning Pathways" [7], "Documentation" [8], and "GitHub Certifications" [9]. Since the task is to find the GitHub Skill section and the 'First day on GitHub' heading, "GitHub Learning Pathways" seems most promising for basic user onboarding or skills-focused content.
Action: Click [7]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.9
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "GitHub Learning Pathways" main section is displayed, which is a likely place to find the GitHub Skill content and the 'First day on GitHub' heading. However, the detailed course list or specific headings are not yet visible. I should scroll down to reveal more content on the page.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.92
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "Pick your pathway" section is visible, displaying several learning pathways (AI-powered development with GitHub Copilot, CI/CD with GitHub Actions, Advanced Security, Administration/Governance). There still isn't a "GitHub Skill" section or a "First day on GitHub" heading yet. To proceed, I need to scroll further down to check for basic onboarding or introductory pathways that might contain what the task is asking for.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.93

Observation: please analyze the attached screenshot and give the Thought and Action. I've provided the tag name of each element and the text it contains (if text exists). Note that <textarea> or <input> may be textbox, but not exactly. Please focus more on the screenshot and then refer to the textual information.
[1]: "Resources", "GitHub resources homepage";	[2]: <button> "Why GitHub", "Show the Why GitHub dropdown menu";	[3]: <button> "Topics", "Show the Topics dropdown menu";	[4]: <button> "Learn", "Show the Learn dropdown menu";	[5]: <button> "Events & Webinars", "Show the Events & Webinars dropdown menu";	[6]: "Enterprise trial";	[7]: "Contact Sales";	[8]: "Explore your GitHub Copilot learning pathway";	[9]: "Explore your automation learning pathway";	[10]: "Explore your security learning pathway";	[11]: "Explore your administration learning pathway";
